page.title: 07FARMING CLAPHAM-NEWBY GEN.
page.content: There are many farms in the area we are studying,because there is plenty of grazing land and lots of water. On the tops of the hills the sheep graze.The lower, richer fields are where the dairy cattle live.Some fields have both sheep and cattle. The cattle are mostly Frisian but some are Charolais also.The sheep are mostly Dalesbred. The sheep are dipped and clipped in June and July.The fleeces are rolled up and put in to bags and taken to Bradford,or exported to Japan. The lambing time is from February to April.The higher the land the later the lambing because of the coldness. Most farms hay-make,or silo.Silo is made earlier than hay,so you can get a good second crop.A common time for hay-making is late June,unless the weather is too bad.
